bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, May 15, 1921

div1.p: Hanson discusses financial affairs and describes various yellow fever cases.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, May 15, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION
de la
CAMPANA SANITARIA
contra la Fiebre Amarilla
et los Departamentos del Norte
C O P Y
THB
Havana
Chiclayo, May 15, 1921.
Funds
OFICINA CENTRAL
Dr. Wickliffe Rose, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York N. Y.
My dear Dr. Rose:
div1.p:
Last night I returned from my tour of inspection of the Department of
Libertad, and the examination of the cases of yellow fever reported from Trujillo.
As I have already informed you both by cable and letter from Trujillo, yellow fever
exists in Trujillo, but is in its initial stages, which I will explain in more
detail later.

On my return I found your letters of April the 6th (two of them), of the
7th, and 12th all of which I have carefully noted. By the first letter of April
6th I notice that you had already made the appropriation of the $15,000.00 before
you received my cable about the financial situation. In regard to the use of a
portion of this money I have already notified you that we have cashed one check
for $5000.00 here in the Banco Mercantil Americano del Peru, in Chiclayo. This
was turned into Peruvian currency at the rate of $3.62 for the Peruvian pound. Of
the money spent here in this Department and in the Province of Pacasmayo Mr.
Guildstrand is preparing a statement which we will send in the same mail with this
letter.

On the ninth of May I opened an account in the Banco Mercantil Americano
in Trujillo, with $5000.00 of your funds at the rate of $3.65 for the Peruvian
pound, and received a net credit in the Bank of Lp 1355.8.14. I enclose copy of
the Bank's statement of this transaction. It is rather unfortunate that these
funds can not all be handled from the same bank. The banks however do not like
to take checks on banks in different departments and for that reason we have the
different accounts for the campaigns in the department in which the money is to
be spent.

In regard to the fever in the southern section of the Department of
Libertad, I saw three cases while in Trujillo, one of which was the Jap mentioned
in my letter of May 6th written from Trujillo, another in the case of a woman in
the hospital and later another case was admitted to the Hospital the day before I
left. In addition one of the Doctors came to my room the night before I left giving
me the history of another case which he had seen that day, which according to the
history is also a case of yellow fever.

On Sunday May the 8th in company with Dr. Tapia, the Medico Sanitario
Departamental, for Libertad, I went for an inspection of the work in the towns of
Ascope and Chocope, and while at Ascope we were notified of a case of suspicious
illness in one of the peones from the Hacienda Casa Grandae. This man had come to
Ascope to consult the Doctor there because he did not get along as well as he
thought he should under the treatment of the Doctor at the Hacienda. When I saw
him he had pronounced congested and yellow conjunctivae and was very much prostrated,
and was vomiting in the train. Examination of the urine showed an abundance of
albumen. He also had epigastric tenderness and pain across his kidneys. Tongue
with red margins pointed very red at tip and a heavy coat dorsally. Diagnosis
yellow fever. On account of finding this case we proceeded from Ascope to Casa
Grande where we met the Doctor of the hacienda and spoke to him about the case. He
denied that he had had such a case, and even after examining the case with us would
not accept the diagnosis of yellow fever. He also showed me another case in a soldier
in the hospital, which in my opinion was yellow fever. This soldier had an abundance
of albumen in the urine, yet this Doctor did not care to accept a diagnosis of yellow
fever. I do not think he has ever seen yellow fever, and therefore his opinion does
not mean anything to me. He is the only physician whom I encountered unreasonable
and inclined to be pigheaded in his opinions. In addition to the cases mentioned
there is a clear history of a case dying in Paijan.

The work there for the present is organized with Dr. Tapia as the
3. W.R., I.H.B.
Director pro tem for the Department, or rather for the Province of Trujillo.
Dr. Ricardo has the Province of Pacasmayo and has done very good work there, so
much so that there will be no epidemic of yellow fever in this province. Dr.
Mendoza has his stegomya index now at from .6% in San Pedro, 1.% in Chepen and in
the rest of the towns it is about 2%. Nearly all the larvae which I saw in my
inspection were of from one to five days growth. The local authorities there are
giving splendid cooperation.

In the province of Trujillo I have left Dr. Enrique Caballero, Sr. Manuel
Machado and Sr. Ramirez in addition to Inspector Jorge Reyes whom I left in charge
of the work in the city of Trujillo. These are all of them the choice of the men
we had in the campaign of last year and can and will do good work. These are all
well known to Dr. Carter.

Since returning I have received your cable in regard to Pickett and
Corrigan. I presume these are the same men that I had last year in Piura, and
will be of very great value to the campaign. These I will use in the Province of
Trujillo, and with this reinforcement I shall feel very much safer.

The Prefecto in Trujillo has accepted the diagnosis and indicated his
readiness to carry out strictly all my orders. We decided to place the “cordon
sanitario” to the south of Viru where there seems that there is only one road
communicating with the next Department to the south. This desert is a large one
and will lend itself to defense better than the others over which the epidemic
has advanced.

In the budget which I presented I had included Dr. Mendoza in your
budget, but he says he thinks the Government should pay his salary and expenses,
and I think he is right and will so arrange matters if possible.

The epidemic in this Department seems to be controlled, the stegomya
index is falling steadily as are also the new cases of fever. The stegomya index
in Chiclayo for the past week was 1.94%.

As soon as I have arranged certain matters of importance in this office
4. W.R., I.H.B.
I expect to return to Trujillo. I am handicapped for the present in my movements
on account of schedule of the steamers. The steamers touch the ports quarantined
very irregularly, and it often happens that I need to make rapid trips from one
Department to the other, which at the present time can not be made by auto by land
on account of the water in the low places in the desert. This water comes from the
snow and rain in the mountains, and at this season of the year. Later on all this
section will be perfectly dry and can be passed in an auto. I have been thinking
of asking the Government to put one of their small cruisers for duty along the coast
so as to enable me to transfer men whenever necessary and to have means of going from
one place to another for inspections.

In another letter I have mentioned Mr. Richardson for the work in the
Department of Libertad, but it seems that Wrightson has started anti-stegomya work
in Callao and kept Mr. Richardson for that work. With the arrival of Pickett and
Corrigan I think we will have sufficient supervision and with their assistance we
ought to make the campaign a real success this year.

Mr. M. M. Seeley is supervising the work in this Department (Lambayeque)
and has helped a great deal to improve the inspection service, for stegomya.

My greatest worry is some one to manage the finances in Libertad during
my absence.

In regard to the use of fish, I beg to report that we are using all the
fish we can get in all parts. Here we have a tank in which we have placed about a
thousand fish for distribution. In Pascasmayo all the “Millones” died, I do not know
what the reason. I shall ask for more and try a breeding place here under the care
of Sr. Arturo Mandichy who is a former Guayaquil employee, he worked with Dr. M. E.
Connor.

I enclose copy of letter which Dr. W. Paraja of Guayaquil wrote me in
response to my request for fish.

I trust you may be able to send me a Mission Code as none is available in
this section.

Thanking you for your courteous letters and the generous offers of
assistance, I am,
div1.closer:
Very Respectfully yours, Henry Hanson (Signed)
Herny Hanson, M.D.,
Director of Sanitary Campaign.

div1.opener:
Copy:
BANCO MERCANTIL AMERICANO DEL PERU.
------------------------------------
Trujillo, May 10th, 1921 -
Mr. Henry Hanson,
City.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
In conformity with our verbal agreement, we have credited
your account with us, provisionally, and under usual reserve, with
Lp.1.355.8.14, being the equivalent of your draft on New York for
$5,000.00, drawn on the Equitable Trust Co., as shown in the corres-
ponding liquidation.

Expressing our thanks for having started your account
with us and wishing that our services would prove to be satisfactory.

closer.salute: We are Dear Sir, yours very truly,
closer.signed:
BANCO MERCANTIL AMERICANO DEL PERU
(Signed by Manager)
